title: Be The Inventor
challengeText: Your challenge will be to invent a machine to haul logs out of the forest! For each of the five challenges, drag and drop your best guess to the Lombard Hauler.

title: 1. The Power Challenge
challengeText: Lumbermen used horses to haul timber from the forest to the nearest river or railroad. This work was very hard on the horses. Horses couldn't pull a heavy logging sled more than a few miles while lumbermen needed to go deeper into the woods to harvest the logs. What power source do you think would work better?

options.label: Oxen
options.feedback: Sorry, incorrect! Oxen are tougher and stronger than horses however, oxen are very slow so they weren't suitable. Try a different solution.

title: 2. The Traction Challenge
challengeText: Lumbermen usually moved timber during the winter when the ground was frozen and sleds could easily glide over ice and snow roads. Designing a machine that would work in those conditions was rather tricky! What solution would provide the right traction for snowy roads?

options.label: Crawler Tracks
options.feedback: Excellent - That's correct!! In 1900 Alvin Lombard developed and patented the first practical crawler track system. Crawler tracks spread the weight of the machine so it can move over soft ground and have plenty of traction on ice and snow. Try the next challenge.

title: 3. The Steering Challenge
challengeText: The Lombard Log hauler with it's heavy steam engine and big crawler tracks weighed 19-tons. How can such a heavy machine be steered?

options.label: Tiller
options.feedback: Sorry, not right. Tiller steering - using a stick to pivot the front wheels - was used on early automobiles. In fact, Alvin Lombard built a steam powered automobile in 1899 that used tiller steering. However, steering with a tiller would be difficult with such a heavy machine. Try another option.

title: 4. The Cost Challenge
challengeText: The Lombard steam Log Hauler worked great, but it was pretty expensive to operate. How can cost be reduced?

options.label: A Smaller Crew
options.feedback: Sorry, incorrect. A Lombard steam log hauler required a crew of three: Steersman, Engineer and fireman. All were vital to the successful and safe operation of the machine. Reducing the crew would create many problems. Try another solution.

In 1915 he introduced the Lombard "Tractor-Truck" which was so successful that he stopped production of steam powered Log haulers in 1917. The "Tractor-Truck" was smaller lighter, faster, required only a driver to operate. Give the last challenge a go.

title: 5. The Braking Challenge
challengeText: A Lombard steam Log Hauler weighed 19 tons and could pull up to 300 tons of logs loaded on sleds. Going down a hill is going to be a challenge! Which option would work as brakes for the hauler?

options.label: Straw
options.feedback: Sorry, wrong answer. When horses were used to pull logging sleds, lumbermen placed straw on the hills to create friction to hold the sleds back. This also worked well for the much bigger steam log haulers. It was expensive because it required a person stationed at each hill to remove the old wet, ice coated straw and lay down a new layer. Try again.

options.label: Mechanical Brakes
options.feedback: Great choice! Steam powered Lombard log haulers never had brakes. However, with the introduction of the Lombard Lag Bed tractor in 1912 all gasoline powered Lombards had a powerful, foot operated drum brake mounted on the drive shaft.

options.feedback: Sorry, incorrect.
